Title.evidence: Open-Label Placebo and Conditioning in Postoperative Pain Management: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The unit of randomisation was the individual patient.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to either the COLP group or a treatment-as-usual group

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the efficacy of combining conditioning with open-label placebos (COLP) to reduce opioid use and postsurgical pain in spine surgery patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was daily opioid consumption measured in morphine milligram equivalents from postoperative day (POD) 1 to POD 17.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the COLP group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Patients in the COLP group consumed 30% less daily morphine milligram equivalents compared to the control group (−14.5; 95% CI: [−26.8, −2.2]).
